prompt_init: You will receive a text. Your task is to rephrase this text without modifying its meaning. Just output your new text, nothing else. Here is the text:
prompt_update: You will receive a text. Your task is to rephrase this text without modifying its meaning. Just output your new text, nothing else. Here is the text:
initial_story:
A US Army soldier stationed in South Korea has been detained in Russia, the US military says.

The Russian foreign ministry said the charges were not related to "politics or espionage", but to a "purely domestic crime".

The 34-year-old was not on official travel when he was held on 2 May in the city of Vladivostok, in Russia's Far East.

Sgt Black had been in the process of changing duty stations from South Korea to Fort Cavazos in the US state of Texas, according to a statement from the US Army.

But instead of returning to the US, he travelled through China to Vladivostok for personal reasons, US Army spokeswoman Cynthia Smith said in a statement.

According to Russian media, he was visiting a woman with whom he had a romantic relationship.

The soldier's mother, Melody Jones, confirmed to CBS that he was in Russia visiting his girlfriend.

"Please do not torture him [or] hurt him," Melody Jones said when asked about her message to the Russians.

Sgt Black enlisted as an infantryman in 2008 and was deployed to Iraq in 2009 and Afghanistan in 2013. He was most recently assigned to the Eighth Army, US Forces Korea at Camp Humphreys in South Korea.

He did not request official clearance and the defence department did not authorise his travel to China or Russia, the US Army said. There is no evidence he intended to remain in Russia.

The Russian interior ministry informed the US embassy in Moscow on 3 May that Sgt Black had been arrested a day earlier for theft of personal property.

He is being held at a pre-trial detention facility until his next hearing.

"The Army notified his family and the US Department of State is providing appropriate consular support to the Soldier in Russia," the US Army said in a statement on Monday.

National Security Council spokesman John Kirby told reporters the US is "aware of this case and other matters related to Russia".

At the White House briefing on Monday, Mr Kirby said he could not provide more details.

Russia is holding two other Americans. Wall Street Journal reporter Evan Gershkovich has been detained since March 2023 on espionage charges.

Former US Marine Paul Whelan was accused of spying and sentenced to 16 years in prison in 2020.

Both men maintain their innocence, and the US government says the charges against them are baseless.
stories:
A US Army soldier, stationed in South Korea, has been taken into custody in Russia, according to the US military.

The Russian foreign ministry claims the charges against the soldier are unrelated to political or espionage activities, but rather a common criminal offense.

The 34-year-old soldier was not on official duty when he was detained on May 2 in Vladivostok, a city located in Russia's Far East.

At the time of his arrest, Sgt Black was in the process of transferring duty stations from South Korea to Fort Cavazos in Texas, USA.

Instead of returning to the US, he traveled to Vladivostok via China for personal reasons, according to a US Army spokesperson.

Russian media reports suggest he was visiting a woman with whom he had a romantic relationship.

The soldier's mother has confirmed to CBS that he was in Russia visiting his girlfriend and has appealed to the Russian authorities not to harm him.

Sgt Black enlisted in the infantry in 2008 and has served in Iraq and Afghanistan.

He did not obtain official clearance for his trip to China and Russia, and the US Department of Defense did not authorize his travel.

There is no evidence to suggest he intended to remain in Russia.

The Russian interior ministry informed the US embassy in Moscow that Sgt Black had been arrested for theft of personal property.

He is currently being held at a pre-trial detention facility awaiting his next hearing.

The US Army has notified his family and the US Department of State is providing consular support to the soldier in Russia.

The National Security Council has acknowledged the case, but declined to provide further details.

Russia is currently holding two other Americans, including a Wall Street Journal reporter and a former US Marine, both of whom maintain their innocence and are backed by the US government.

A 34-year-old US Army sergeant, who was stationed in South Korea and in the process of being transferred to a base in Texas, was detained in Vladivostok, Russia on May 2, according to the US military. Russian authorities claim the sergeant was arrested for a common criminal offense, unrelated to espionage or political activities. The sergeant, who was not on official duty at the time, had traveled to Vladivostok via China for personal reasons, reportedly to visit a romantic partner. The Russian interior ministry alleges he stole personal property, and he is currently being held in a pre-trial detention facility. The US Army has notified his family, and the US Department of State is providing consular support. The National Security Council is aware of the case, but has declined to comment further. Notably, Russia is also holding two other Americans, a journalist and a former Marine, both of whom deny any wrongdoing and have the support of the US government.

A US Army sergeant, aged 34, was apprehended in Vladivostok, Russia on May 2, while in transit from South Korea to a new posting in Texas, the US military has confirmed. Russian officials assert that the sergeant's arrest was unrelated to espionage or political activities, instead citing a common criminal offense. The sergeant, who was not on duty at the time, had traveled to Vladivostok via China for personal reasons, reportedly to visit a romantic partner. According to the Russian interior ministry, the sergeant is accused of theft and is currently being detained pending trial. The US Army has informed the sergeant's family and the US Department of State is providing consular assistance. Although the National Security Council is aware of the situation, it has declined to comment further. It is worth noting that Russia is also detaining two other Americans, a journalist and a former Marine, both of whom deny any wrongdoing and are receiving support from the US government.

According to Russian officials, the arrest is connected to an ongoing criminal investigation, with no suggestion of espionage or political motivations. The sergeant, who had stopped over in Vladivostok to visit his partner after arriving from China, is now facing theft charges and is awaiting his trial. The US Army has notified the sergeant's family, and the State Department is providing assistance. Although the National Security Council is aware of the situation, it has declined to make further comments. It's worth noting that two other American citizens, a journalist and a former Marine, are also being detained in Russia, both of whom deny any wrongdoing and are receiving support from the US government.
